docs.comment:
/** *

Finds a near optimal approximation to the real roots (or those * within a range) of the input polynomial. *

*

* Only multiple roots of even order that is very close together may be * missed. (This is rarely a problem in practice - in a geometrical * application, for instance, this may mean two objects are barely * touching and returning either, all, or none of the repeated even * roots should not break the algorithm). *

* * @alias allRoots * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial * @param {number} a - Lower limit of root values that should be * returned - defaults to -∞ * @param {number} b - Upper limit of root values that should be * returned - defaults to +∞ * @returns {number[]} The found roots. * @impl_notes * @example * FloPoly.allRoots([1, -10, 35, -50, 24]); //=> [1, 2.0000000000000036, 3.0000000000000067, 4] */
docs.description:
Finds a near optimal approximation to the real roots (or those within a range) of the input polynomial.

Only multiple roots of even order that is very close together may be missed. (This is rarely a problem in practice - in a geometrical application, for instance, this may mean two objects are barely touching and returning either, all, or none of the repeated even roots should not break the algorithm).

params.description: Lower limit of root values that should be returned - defaults to -∞
params.name: a

params.description: Upper limit of root values that should be returned - defaults to +∞
params.name: b

docs.name: allRoots

docs.comment:
/**
 * Returns a function that returns true if x is in the range [a,b].
 *  
 * @ignore
 * @param {number} a
 * @param {number} b
 * @returns {function}
 */
docs.description: Returns a function that returns true if x is in the range [a,b].
docs.name: inRange

docs.comment:
/**
 * Finds all roots of the given polynomial within the given intervals.
 *  
 * @ignore
 * @param {number[]} p
 * @param {number[]} intervals
 * @returns {number[]} The found roots.
 */
docs.description: Finds all roots of the given polynomial within the given intervals.
docs.name: rootsWithin

docs.comment:
/** 
 * DO NOT USE. EXPERIMENTAL.
 * Find all the roots using the VAS algorithm followed by Brent's 
 * method.
 *  
 * @ignore
 * @param {number[]} p - A square-free polynomial.
 * @returns {number[]} The roots.
 **/
docs.description: DO NOT USE. EXPERIMENTAL.Find all the roots using the VAS algorithm followed by Brent's method.
docs.name: allRootsVAS

docs.comment:
/**
 * Removes the zero roots from the polynomial.
 * 
 * @ignore
 * @returns {number[]} The deflated polynomial.
 *       
 */
docs.description: Removes the zero roots from the polynomial.
docs.name: removeZeroRoots

docs.comment:
/** 
 * Finds root intervals of a polynomial such that each interval contains
 * exactly one root using the VAS (Vincent–Akritas–Strzeboński) method.
 * 
 * @ignore
 * @see http://www.e-ce.uth.gr/wp-content/uploads/formidable/phd_thesis_vigklas.pdf
 */
docs.description: Finds root intervals of a polynomial such that each interval containsexactly one root using the VAS (Vincent–Akritas–Strzeboński) method.
docs.name: vasRootIntervals

docs.comment:
/** 
 * Helper function
 * The initial mobius transformation must be [[1,0],[0,1]] = M(x) = x.
 * 
 * @ignore
 */
docs.description: Helper functionThe initial mobius transformation must be [[1,0],[0,1]] = M(x) = x.
docs.name: vasRootIntervalsHelper

docs.comment:
/**
 * Adds two polynomials.
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p1 - The first polynomial
 * @param {number[]} p2 - The second polynomial
 * @returns {number[]} p1 + p2.
 * @example
 * FloPoly.add([1,2,3],[3,4]); //=> [1,5,7]
 */
docs.description: Adds two polynomials.
docs.name: add

docs.comment:
/** 
 * Subtracts the second polynomial from first.
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p1 - The polynomial from which will be subtracted
 * @param {number[]} p2 - The polynomial that will be subtracted
 * @returns {number[]} p1 - p2
 * @example
 * FloPoly.subtract([2,3],[4,4]); //=> [-2, -1]
 */
docs.description: Subtracts the second polynomial from first.

params.description: The polynomial from which will be subtracted
params.name: p1

params.description: The polynomial that will be subtracted
params.name: p2

docs.name: subtract

docs.comment:
/**
 * Negate the given polynomial (p -> -p).  
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @returns {number[]} -p
 * @example
 * FloPoly.negate([0.1, -0.2]); //=> [-0.1, 0.2]
 */
docs.description: Negate the given polynomial (p -> -p).
docs.name: negate

docs.comment:
/**  
 * Differentiates the given polynomial.
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @returns {number[]} D(p)
 * @example
 * FloPoly.differentiate([5, 4, 3, 2, 1]); //=> [20, 12, 6, 2]
 */
docs.description: Differentiates the given polynomial.
docs.name: differentiate

docs.comment:
/** 
 * Multiplies the two given polynomials and returns the result. 
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p1 - The one polynomial.
 * @param {number[]} p2 - The other polynomial.
 * @returns {number[]} p1 * p2
 * 
 * @see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynomial_arithmetic 
 * @see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_Fourier_transform#Polynomial_multiplication
 * @see http://web.cs.iastate.edu/~cs577/handouts/polymultiply.pdf
 * 
 * @example
 * FloPoly.multiply([1,2,3], [2,5,3,5]); //=> [2, 9, 19, 26, 19, 15]
 */
docs.description: Multiplies the two given polynomials and returns the result.
docs.name: multiply

docs.comment:
/** 
 * Multiplies 2 polynomials by a constant.
 * 
 * @param {number} c - The constant
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @returns {number[]} c*p
 * @example 
 * FloPoly.multiplyByConst(0.25, [3,2,1]); //=> [0.75, 0.5, 0.25]  
 */
docs.description: Multiplies 2 polynomials by a constant.
docs.name: multiplyByConst

docs.comment:
/** 
 * Returns the degree of the polynomial.
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @returns {number} 
 * @example 
 * FloPoly.degree([9,8,7,6,5,4,3,2,1]); //=> 9
 */
docs.description: Returns the degree of the polynomial.
docs.name: degree

docs.comment:
/** 
 * Evaluates a univariate polynomial using Horner's method. This 
 * function is curried (see examples below).  
 * 
 * @see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horner%27s_method
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @param {number} a - The value at which to evaluate the polynomial.
 * @returns {number|function} The result if both parameters are supplied
 * or a function with arity one if only the first parameter is supplied.
 * @example
 * let ev = FloPoly.evaluate([3,2,1]);
 * ev(1); // => 6
 * ev(2); // => 17
 * 		 
 * FloPoly.evaluate([3,2,1], 1); // => 6
 * FloPoly.evaluate([3,2,1], 2); // => 17
 * 
 * FloPoly.evaluate([3,2,1])(1); // => 6
 * FloPoly.evaluate([3,2,1])(2); // => 17
 */
docs.description: Evaluates a univariate polynomial using Horner's method. This function is curried (see examples below).

params.description: The value at which to evaluate the polynomial.
params.name: a

returns.description: The result if both parameters are suppliedor a function with arity one if only the first parameter is supplied.

examples: let ev = FloPoly.evaluate([3,2,1]);ev(1); // => 6ev(2); // => 17		 FloPoly.evaluate([3,2,1], 1); // => 6FloPoly.evaluate([3,2,1], 2); // => 17FloPoly.evaluate([3,2,1])(1); // => 6FloPoly.evaluate([3,2,1])(2); // => 17
docs.name: evaluate

docs.comment:
/** 
 * Evaluates the given polynomial at 0 - it is much faster than at an 
 * arbitrary point. 
 *  
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @returns {number}
 * @example
 * FloPoly.evaluateAt0([3,2,99]); //=> 99
 */
docs.description: Evaluates the given polynomial at 0 - it is much faster than at an arbitrary point.
docs.name: evaluateAt0

docs.comment:
/** *

* Returns the number of sign changes in the polynomial coefficents * when ordered in descending order; zeros are ignored. *

*

* Descartes' rule of signs states (quoted from Wikipedia): * "if the terms of a polynomial are ordered by descending variable * exponent, then the number of positive roots of the polynomial is * either equal to the number of sign differences between consecutive * nonzero coefficients, or is less than it by an even number. Multiple * roots of the same value are counted separately." *

* @see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Descartes%27_rule_of_signs * * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial * @returns {number} The number of sign changes. * @example * FloPoly.signChanges([1,2,-3,0,0,3,-1]); //=> 3 */
docs.description:
Returns the number of sign changes in the polynomial coefficents when ordered in descending order; zeros are ignored.

Descartes' rule of signs states (quoted from Wikipedia): "if the terms of a polynomial are ordered by descending variable exponent, then the number of positive roots of the polynomial is either equal to the number of sign differences between consecutive nonzero coefficients, or is less than it by an even number. Multiple roots of the same value are counted separately."
docs.name: signChanges

docs.comment:
/**
 * Deflates the given polynomial by removing a factor (x - r), where
 * r is a root of the polynomial.
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @param {number} root - A pre-calculated root of the polynomial.
 * @returns {number[]} The deflated polynomial.
 * @example
 * // The polynomial x^3 - 5x^2 + 8x - 4 has a root at 1 and a double root at 2 
 * FloPoly.deflate([1, -5, 8, -4], 2); //=> [1, -3, 2] 
 * FloPoly.deflate([1, -3, 2], 2);     //=> [1,-1] 
 * FloPoly.deflate([1, -1], 1);        //=> [1]
 */
docs.description: Deflates the given polynomial by removing a factor (x - r), wherer is a root of the polynomial.

params.description: A pre-calculated root of the polynomial.
params.name: root

examples: // The polynomial x^3 - 5x^2 + 8x - 4 has a root at 1 and a double root at 2 FloPoly.deflate([1, -5, 8, -4], 2); //=> [1, -3, 2] FloPoly.deflate([1, -3, 2], 2);     //=> [1,-1] FloPoly.deflate([1, -1], 1);        //=> [1]
docs.name: deflate

docs.comment:
/**
 * Inverts the given polynomial by reversing the order of the 
 * coefficients.
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @returns {number} p(x) -> x^deg(p) * p(1/x)
 * @example
 * FloPoly.invert([1,2,3,4]); // => [4,3,2,1]
 * FloPoly.invert([3,2,-5]);  // => [-5,2,3]
 */
docs.description: Inverts the given polynomial by reversing the order of the coefficients.
docs.name: invert

docs.comment:
/** 
 * Performs a change of variables of the form: p(x) <- p(ax + b).
 * @see http://stackoverflow.com/questions/141422/how-can-a-transform-a-polynomial-to-another-coordinate-system
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @param {number} a
 * @param {number} b
 * @returns {number[]} The transformed polynomial.
 * @example
 * FloPoly.changeVariables([1,2,7], 3, 4); //=> [9, 30, 31]
 */
docs.description: Performs a change of variables of the form: p(x) <- p(ax + b).
docs.name: changeVariables

docs.comment:
/**
 * Reflects the given polynomial about the Y-axis, i.e. perform the 
 * change of variables: p(x) <- p(-x).
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial to reflect
 * @returns {number[]} The reflected polynomial.
 * @example
 * FloPoly.reflectAboutYAxis([5,4,3,2,1]); //=> [5, -4, 3, -2, 1]
 */
docs.description: Reflects the given polynomial about the Y-axis, i.e. perform the change of variables: p(x) <- p(-x).
docs.name: reflectAboutYAxis

docs.comment:
/** 
 * Generates a sturm chain for the given polynomial.
 * 
 * @see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sturm%27s_theorem
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @returns {number[][]} The sturm chain of polynomials
 * @example
 * FloPoly.sturmChain([-3,4,2,-2]); //=> [[-3, 4, 2, -2], [-9, 8, 2], [-2.5185185185185186, 1.7037037037037037], [-3.2932525951557086]]
 */
docs.description: Generates a sturm chain for the given polynomial.
docs.name: sturmChain

docs.comment:
/** 
	 * Returns the negative of the remainder when dividing the first 
	 * polynomial (the dividend) by the second (the divisor) provided 
	 * that deg(p1) - deg(p2) === 1.
	 * 
	 * @ignore
	 * @param {number[]} p1 - The first polynomial (dividend)
	 * @param {number[]} p2 - The second polynomial (divisor)
	 * @see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sturm%27s_theorem
	 */
docs.description: Returns the negative of the remainder when dividing the first polynomial (the dividend) by the second (the divisor) provided that deg(p1) - deg(p2) === 1.
docs.name: negRemainder

docs.comment:
/**
 * If the highest power coefficient is small in the sense that the 
 * highest power term has a negligible contribution (compared to the
 * other terms) at x = 1 then clip() can be called to remove all such 
 * highest terms. A contribution of less than Number.EPSILON of the 
 * highest coefficient will be considered negligible by default.
 * 
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial to be clipped.
 * @param {number} δ_ - The optional contribution tolerence else 
 *        Number.EPSILON will be used by default.   
 * @returns {number[]} The clipped polynomial.
 * @example
 * FloPoly.clip([1e-18, 1e-10, 1e-5]); //=> [1e-18, 1e-10, 1e-5] 
 * FloPoly.clip([1e-18, 1e-10, 1e-1]); //=> [1e-10, 1e-1]
 */
docs.description: If the highest power coefficient is small in the sense that the highest power term has a negligible contribution (compared to theother terms) at x = 1 then clip() can be called to remove all such highest terms. A contribution of less than Number.EPSILON of the highest coefficient will be considered negligible by default.

params.description: The optional contribution tolerence else        Number.EPSILON will be used by default.
params.name: δ_

docs.name: clip

docs.comment:
/**
 * If the highest power coefficient is 0 then clip() can be called to 
 * remove all such highest terms so that the array is a valid 
 * presentation of a polynomial.
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial to be clipped.
 * @returns {number[]} The clipped polynomial.
 * @example
 * FloPoly.clip0([1e-18, 1e-10, 1e-1]); //=> [1e-18, 1e-10, 1e-1]
 * FloPoly.clip0([0, 1e-10, 1e-1]); //=> [1e-10, 1e-1]
 */
docs.description: If the highest power coefficient is 0 then clip() can be called to remove all such highest terms so that the array is a valid presentation of a polynomial.
docs.name: clip0

docs.comment:
/**
 * Returns the absolute value of the highest coefficient of the 
 * polynomial.
 * 
 * @param p {number[]} p - The polynomial.
 * @returns {number}
 * @example
 * FloPoly.maxCoefficient([-2, 0.1, 0.2]); //=> 2
 */
docs.description: Returns the absolute value of the highest coefficient of the polynomial.
docs.name: maxCoefficient

docs.comment:
/**
 * Returns a string representing the given polynomial that is readable 
 * by a human or a CAS (Computer Algebra System).
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @returns {string}
 * @example
 * FloPoly.toCasStr([5,4,3,2,1]); //=> "x^4*5 + x^3*4 + x^2*3 + x*2 + 1"
 */
docs.description: Returns a string representing the given polynomial that is readable by a human or a CAS (Computer Algebra System).
docs.name: toCasStr

docs.comment:
/** *

* Simple & fast practical library functions for functional univariate * polynomials over the reals (actually ECMAScript numbers, i.e. double * floats). *

*

* All polinomials are represented as a simple array starting with the * highest non-zero power, e.g. * 3x^3 + 5x^2 + 7x + 2 -> [3,5,7,2] *

* @ignore */
docs.description:
Simple & fast practical library functions for functional univariate polynomials over the reals (actually ECMAScript numbers, i.e. double floats).

All polinomials are represented as a simple array starting with the highest non-zero power, e.g. 3x^3 + 5x^2 + 7x + 2 -> [3,5,7,2]
docs.name: FloPoly

docs.comment:
/** *

* Constructs a polynomial from the given roots by multiplying out the * factors (x - root1)(x - root2)... Note that the resulting polynomial * will not have any complex roots. *

*

* Mostly provided for testing purposes. Note that the real roots of the * constructed polynomial may not be exactly the same as the roots that * the polynomial has been constructed from due to floating-point * round-off. *

* * @param {number[]} roots - The roots * @returns {number[]} The constructed polynomial. * @example * FloPoly.fromRoots([1,2,3,3]); //=> [1, -9, 29, -39, 18] * FloPoly.allRoots([1, -9, 29, -39, 18]); //=> [1.0000000000000007, 2.000000000000004] * // In the above note the rounding error. Also note the multiple root of 3 that has been missed but as stated previously this does not generally pose a problem for even multiple roots. See the examples below. * FloPoly.allRoots([1, -9, 29, -39, 17.99999999999999]); //=> [0.9999999999999973, 2.00000000000002, 2.9999999999999982] * FloPoly.allRoots([1, -9, 29, -39, 17.9999999999999]); //=> [0.999999999999975, 2.0000000000000986, 2.9999997898930832, 3.0000002095475775] */
docs.description:
Constructs a polynomial from the given roots by multiplying out the factors (x - root1)(x - root2)... Note that the resulting polynomial will not have any complex roots.

Mostly provided for testing purposes. Note that the real roots of the constructed polynomial may not be exactly the same as the roots that the polynomial has been constructed from due to floating-point round-off.
examples: FloPoly.fromRoots([1,2,3,3]); //=> [1, -9, 29, -39, 18]FloPoly.allRoots([1, -9, 29, -39, 18]); //=> [1.0000000000000007, 2.000000000000004]// In the above note the rounding error. Also note the multiple root of 3 that has been missed but as stated previously this does not generally pose a problem for even multiple roots. See the examples below.FloPoly.allRoots([1, -9, 29, -39, 17.99999999999999]); //=> [0.9999999999999973, 2.00000000000002, 2.9999999999999982]FloPoly.allRoots([1, -9, 29, -39, 17.9999999999999]); //=> [0.999999999999975, 2.0000000000000986, 2.9999997898930832, 3.0000002095475775]
docs.name: fromRoots

docs.comment:
/**
 * Operators (i.e. functions) directly related to roots and root 
 * finding. 
 * 
 * @ignore
 */
docs.description: Operators (i.e. functions) directly related to roots and root finding.
docs.name: rootOperators

docs.comment:
/** *

* Floating-point-stably calculates and returns the ordered quadratic * roots of the given quadratic polynomial. *

*

* This function is included only because it might be slightly faster * than calling allRoots due to allRoots first checking if the * polynomial is quadratic and checking if the roots are within the * given range. *

* @param {number[]} p - The 2nd order polynomial * @returns {number[]} The found quadratic roots. * @example * FloPoly.quadraticRoots([1, -3, 2]); //=> [1,2] */
docs.description:
Floating-point-stably calculates and returns the ordered quadratic roots of the given quadratic polynomial.

This function is included only because it might be slightly faster than calling allRoots due to allRoots first checking if the polynomial is quadratic and checking if the roots are within the given range.
docs.name: quadraticRoots

docs.comment:
/** 
 * Returns the number of real roots in the interval (a,b) of the given 
 * polynomial.
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @param {number} a - The lower bound
 * @param {number} b - The upper bound
 * @returns {number} The number of roots in the given interval
 * @example 
 * let p = [1, 1, -64, 236, -240];
 * FloPoly.numRootsWithin(p,-20,-11); //=> 0
 * FloPoly.numRootsWithin(p,-11,-9);  //=> 1  
 * FloPoly.numRootsWithin(p,-11,3.5); //=> 3
 * FloPoly.numRootsWithin(p,-11,5);   //=> 4
 */
docs.description: Returns the number of real roots in the interval (a,b) of the given polynomial.

returns.description: The number of roots in the given interval

examples: let p = [1, 1, -64, 236, -240];FloPoly.numRootsWithin(p,-20,-11); //=> 0FloPoly.numRootsWithin(p,-11,-9);  //=> 1  FloPoly.numRootsWithin(p,-11,3.5); //=> 3FloPoly.numRootsWithin(p,-11,5);   //=> 4
docs.name: numRootsWithin

docs.comment:
/** *

* Searches an interval (a,b) for a root (i.e. zero) of the * given function with respect to its first argument using the Brent's * Method root-finding algorithm. Any function can be supplied (it does * not even have to be continuous) as long as the root is bracketed. *

*

* Brent's Method is an excellent root-finding choice since it is * (1) guaranteed to converge (unlike the Newton and other so-called * single-point methods), (2) converges in a reasonable number of * iterations even for highly contrived functions (unlike Dekker's * Method) and (3) nearly always converges extremely fast, i.e. super- * linearly (unlike the Secant and Regula-Falsi methods). *

*

* The max error, δ, is set equal to 2*Number.EPSILON*Math.abs(b) * + Number.EPSILON after each iteration where b is the current best * guess. A much larger δ of say 1e-10 does not really make sense * for polynomials since nearly always by that stage convergence * proceeds superlinearly and by the next iteration a δ of * around Number.EPSILON is achieved. On the other hand, a δ of * much less than Number.EPSILON is sometimes useful, say for finding * the root of the polynomial x**2 - 3*x*1e-13 + 2*1e-26 to within less * than 1e-15, but this is rare enough not to be considered in this * implementation. (For JavaScript doubles Number.EPSILON === * 2.220446049250313e-16 and since b is typically around 1 the max δ * will be about 3*2.220446049250313e-16 or about 1e-15. As another * example, a root near -1000 will have a max error, i.e. δ, of * about 1e-12. In conclusion, for roots near zero the error can be up * to Number.EPSILON or about 1e-15 - we don't bother to calculate the * root more accurately than this since it may require up to 4 or 5 * additional iterations. *

*

* See Wikipedia *

*

* See Brent (page 47) *

* @param {function} f - The function for which the root is sought. * @param {number} a - The lower limit of the search interval. * @param {number} b - The upper limit of the search interval. * @returns {number} An estimate of the root to within δ (typically * about 1e-15). * @example * let p = FloPoly.fromRoots([-10,2,3,4]); //=> [1, 1, -64, 236, -240] * let f = FloPoly.evaluate(p); * FloPoly.brent(f,2.2,3.8); //=> 3.000000000000003 * FloPoly.brent(f,2.2,3.1); //=> 3.000000000000001 */
docs.description:
Searches an interval (a,b) for a root (i.e. zero) of the given function with respect to its first argument using the Brent's Method root-finding algorithm. Any function can be supplied (it does not even have to be continuous) as long as the root is bracketed.

Brent's Method is an excellent root-finding choice since it is (1) guaranteed to converge (unlike the Newton and other so-called single-point methods), (2) converges in a reasonable number of iterations even for highly contrived functions (unlike Dekker's Method) and (3) nearly always converges extremely fast, i.e. super- linearly (unlike the Secant and Regula-Falsi methods).

The max error, δ, is set equal to 2*Number.EPSILON*Math.abs(b) + Number.EPSILON after each iteration where b is the current best guess. A much larger δ of say 1e-10 does not really make sense for polynomials since nearly always by that stage convergence proceeds superlinearly and by the next iteration a δ of around Number.EPSILON is achieved. On the other hand, a δ of much less than Number.EPSILON is sometimes useful, say for finding the root of the polynomial x**2 - 3*x*1e-13 + 2*1e-26 to within less than 1e-15, but this is rare enough not to be considered in this implementation. (For JavaScript doubles Number.EPSILON === 2.220446049250313e-16 and since b is typically around 1 the max δ will be about 3*2.220446049250313e-16 or about 1e-15. As another example, a root near -1000 will have a max error, i.e. δ, of about 1e-12. In conclusion, for roots near zero the error can be up to Number.EPSILON or about 1e-15 - we don't bother to calculate the root more accurately than this since it may require up to 4 or 5 additional iterations.

See Wikipedia

See Brent (page 47)

params.description: The function for which the root is sought.
params.name: f

params.description: The lower limit of the search interval.
params.name: a

params.description: The upper limit of the search interval.
params.name: b

returns.description: An estimate of the root to within δ (typically about 1e-15).

docs.name: brent

docs.comment:
/**
 * Some seed value for the simple random number generator.
 * @ignore
 */
docs.description: Some seed value for the simple random number generator.
docs.name: SEED

docs.comment:
/**
 * The range for the simple random number generator, i.e. the generated
 * numbers will be in [0,RANGE].
 * @ignore
 */
docs.description: The range for the simple random number generator, i.e. the generatednumbers will be in [0,RANGE].
docs.name: RANGE

docs.comment:
/**
 * Generates an array of random polynomials with parameters as specified 
 * by flatRoots. The exact same polynomials will be created on each
 * call to this function if the same seed is used - this is by design to 
 * improve testability.
 *   
 * @memberof random
 * @param {number} n - The number of polynomials to generate.
 * @param {number} d - The degree of the polynomials 
 * @param {number} a - The lower bound of the distribution - defaults 
 * to 0
 * @param {number} b - The upper bound of the distribution - defaults 
 * to 1
 * @param {number} seed - A seed value for generating random values (so
 * that the results are reproducable)
 * @param {number} odds - The odds that a root will be doubled (applied
 * recursively so that some roots will be tripled, etc. - defaults to 0
 * @returns {number[][]} The array of random polynomials.
 * @example
 * FloPoly.random.flatRootsArr(2,3,0,10); //=> [[1, -17.27247918024659, 97.33487287168995, -179.34094494147305], [1, -14.934967160224915, 57.624514485645406, -14.513933300587215]]
 * FloPoly.random.flatRootsArr(2,3,0,10); //=> [[1, -17.27247918024659, 97.33487287168995, -179.34094494147305], [1, -14.934967160224915, 57.624514485645406, -14.513933300587215]]
 */
docs.description: Generates an array of random polynomials with parameters as specified by flatRoots. The exact same polynomials will be created on eachcall to this function if the same seed is used - this is by design to improve testability.

params.description: The number of polynomials to generate.
params.name: n

params.description: The lower bound of the distribution - defaults to 0
params.name: a

params.description: The upper bound of the distribution - defaults to 1
params.name: b

params.description: A seed value for generating random values (sothat the results are reproducable)
params.name: seed

params.description: The odds that a root will be doubled (appliedrecursively so that some roots will be tripled, etc. - defaults to 0
params.name: odds

docs.name: flatRootsArr

docs.comment:
/**
 * Generates an array of random polynomials as specified by 
 * flatCoefficients. The exact same polynomials will be created on each
 * call to this function if the same seed is used - this is by design to 
 * improve testability.
 *   
 * @memberof random
 * @param {number} n - The number of polynomials to generate.
 * @param {number} d - The degree of the polynomials 
 * @param {number} a - The lower bound of the distribution - defaults 
 * to 0
 * @param {number} b - The upper bound of the distribution - defaults 
 * to 1
 * @param {number} seed - A seed value for generating random values (so
 * that the results are reproducable)
 * @returns {number[][]} The array of random polynomials.
 * @example
 * FloPoly.random.flatCoefficientsArr(2,3,-2,2); //=> [[0.1749166026711464, -0.20349335670471191, 0.9375684261322021], [1.0617692470550537, -1.8918039798736572, 0.8040215969085693]]
 * FloPoly.random.flatCoefficientsArr(2,3,-2,2); //=> [[0.1749166026711464, -0.20349335670471191, 0.9375684261322021], [1.0617692470550537, -1.8918039798736572, 0.8040215969085693]]
 */
docs.description: Generates an array of random polynomials as specified by flatCoefficients. The exact same polynomials will be created on eachcall to this function if the same seed is used - this is by design to improve testability.

params.description: The number of polynomials to generate.

docs.comment:
/**
 * Generates a random array of numbers picked from a bounded flat 
 * distribution (i.e. a rectangular distribution) with specified odds of 
 * duplication of consecutive values.
 *   
 * @ignore
 * @param {number} n - The number of values to generate.
 * @param {number} a - The lower bound of the distribution - defaults 
 * to 0
 * @param {number} b - The upper bound of the distribution - defaults 
 * to 1
 * @param {number} seed - A seed value for generating random values (so
 * that the results are reproducable)
 * @param {number} odds - The odds that a root will be doubled (applied
 * recursively so that some roots will be tripled, etc. - defaults to 0
 * @returns {number[]} - The random array.
 */
docs.description: Generates a random array of numbers picked from a bounded flat distribution (i.e. a rectangular distribution) with specified odds of duplication of consecutive values.

params.description: The number of values to generate.
params.name: n

params.description: The lower bound of the distribution - defaults to 0
params.name: a

params.description: The upper bound of the distribution - defaults to 1
params.name: b

params.description: A seed value for generating random values (sothat the results are reproducable)
params.name: seed

params.description: The odds that a root will be doubled (appliedrecursively so that some roots will be tripled, etc. - defaults to 0
params.name: odds

docs.name: randomArray

docs.comment:
/**
 * Helper function that will add more numbers to the passed array - 
 * modifies the values parameter.
 *
 * @ignore
 * @param {number[]} values - An existing array of values - will be 
 * modified!
 * @param {number} x - The number that will be added (possibly
 * multiple times)
 * @param {number} odds - The odds that the number will be added
 * again (recursively). 
 */
docs.description: Helper function that will add more numbers to the passed array - modifies the values parameter.

params.description: An existing array of values - will be modified!
params.name: values

params.description: The number that will be added (possiblymultiple times)
params.name: x

params.description: The odds that the number will be addedagain (recursively).
params.name: odds

docs.name: push

docs.comment:
/**
 * Generates a random polynomial with roots picked from a bounded flat 
 * distribution (i.e. a rectangular distribution) with specified odds of 
 * duplication of consecutive values. Note that the resulting polynomial
 * won't have any complex roots.
 * 
 * @memberof random
 * @param {number} d - The degree of the polynomials 
 * @param {number} a - The lower bound of the distribution - defaults 
 * to 0
 * @param {number} b - The upper bound of the distribution - defaults 
 * to 1
 * @param {number} seed - A seed value for generating random values (so
 * that the results are reproducable)
 * @param {number} odds - The odds that a root will be doubled (applied
 * recursively so that some roots will be tripled, etc. - defaults to 0
 * @returns {{p: number[], seed: number}} a random polynomial and the
 * last seed value to reuse.
 * @example
 * FloPoly.random.flatRoots(3,0,10); //=> { p: [1, -17.27247918024659, 97.33487287168995, -179.34094494147305], seed: 939629312 }
 */
docs.description: Generates a random polynomial with roots picked from a bounded flat distribution (i.e. a rectangular distribution) with specified odds of duplication of consecutive values. Note that the resulting polynomialwon't have any complex roots.

params.description: The lower bound of the distribution - defaults to 0
params.name: a

params.description: The upper bound of the distribution - defaults to 1
params.name: b

params.description: A seed value for generating random values (sothat the results are reproducable)
params.name: seed

params.description: The odds that a root will be doubled (appliedrecursively so that some roots will be tripled, etc. - defaults to 0
params.name: odds

returns.description: a random polynomial and thelast seed value to reuse.

docs.name: flatRoots

docs.comment:
/**
 * Generates a random polynomial with coefficients picked from a bounded 
 * flat distribution (i.e. a rectangular distribution). 
 * 
 * @memberof random
 * @param {number} d - The degree of the polynomials 
 * @param {number} a - The lower bound of the distribution - defaults 
 * to -1
 * @param {number} b - The upper bound of the distribution - defaults 
 * to 1
 * @param {number} seed - A seed value for generating random values (so
 * that the results are reproducable)
 * @returns {{p: number[], seed: number}} a random polynomial and the
 * last seed value to reuse.
 * @example
 * FloPoly.random.flatCoefficients(3,-5,5); //=> { p: [0.437291506677866, -0.5087333917617798, 2.3439210653305054], seed: 939629312 }
 */
docs.description: Generates a random polynomial with coefficients picked from a bounded flat distribution (i.e. a rectangular distribution).

params.description: The lower bound of the distribution - defaults to -1
params.name: a

params.description: The upper bound of the distribution - defaults to 1
params.name: b

params.description: A seed value for generating random values (sothat the results are reproducable)
params.name: seed

returns.description: a random polynomial and thelast seed value to reuse.

docs.name: flatCoefficients

docs.comment:
/**
 * Creates a function from the given function with parameters similar
 * to flatRoots but with an extra parameter in the beginning indicating
 * the length of the array generated by the original function.
 * 
 * @ignore
 * @param {function} f
 * @returns {function}
 */
docs.description: Creates a function from the given function with parameters similarto flatRoots but with an extra parameter in the beginning indicatingthe length of the array generated by the original function.
docs.name: createArrFunction

docs.comment:
/** 
 * Mobius namespaced functions, i.e. M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) where 
 * a,b,c and d are constants. Represented as a 2-diminsional array 
 * [[a,b],[c,d]].
 * 
 * @ignore
 * @namespace
 */
docs.description: Mobius namespaced functions, i.e. M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) where a,b,c and d are constants. Represented as a 2-diminsional array [[a,b],[c,d]].
docs.name: Mobius

docs.comment:
/**
 * Performs a change of variables x → ax + b on p(x) where
 * it is a precondition on the polynomial p that deg(p) = 1.
 *
 * @ignore
 * @param {number[]} p - The degree 1 polynomial p(x)
 * @param {number} a
 * @param {number} b
 * @returns {number[]} The modified polynomial p(ax + b). 
 */
docs.description: Performs a change of variables x → ax + b on p(x) whereit is a precondition on the polynomial p that deg(p) = 1.
docs.name: changeVariables1

docs.comment:
/**
 * Performs a change of variables x → px + q on the given Mobius 
 * function. 
 *
 * @ignore
 * @param {number[][]} mobius - The mobius function 
 * M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) represented as [[a,b],[c,d]]
 * @param {number} a
 * @param {number} b
 * @returns {number[][]} The modified mobius function 
 * M(x) = (a(px + q) + b) / (c(px + q) + d). 
 */
docs.description: Performs a change of variables x → px + q on the given Mobius function.

params.description: The mobius function M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) represented as [[a,b],[c,d]]
params.name: mobius

returns.description: The modified mobius function M(x) = (a(px + q) + b) / (c(px + q) + d).

docs.name: changeVariables

docs.comment:
/**
 * Inverts the given mobius, i.e.
 * M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) → (bx + a) / (dx + c)
 * 
 * @ignore
 * @param {number[][]} mobius - The mobius function 
 * M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) represented as [[a,b],[c,d]]
 * @returns {number[][]} The modified mobius function. 
 */
docs.description: Inverts the given mobius, i.e.M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) → (bx + a) / (dx + c)

params.description: The mobius function M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) represented as [[a,b],[c,d]]
params.name: mobius

docs.name: invert

docs.comment:
/**
 * Evaluates the given mobius function at x = 0.
 * 
 * @ignore
 * @param {number[][]} mobius - The mobius function 
 * M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) represented as [[a,b],[c,d]]
 * @returns {number} The result of the evaluation.
 */
docs.description: Evaluates the given mobius function at x = 0.

params.description: The mobius function M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) represented as [[a,b],[c,d]]
params.name: mobius

docs.name: evaluateAt0

docs.comment:
/**
 * Evaluates the given mobius function in the limit as x → ∞.
 * 
 * @ignore
 * @param {number[][]} mobius - The mobius function 
 * M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) represented as [[a,b],[c,d]]
 * @returns {number} The result of the evaluation.
 */
docs.description: Evaluates the given mobius function in the limit as x → ∞.

params.description: The mobius function M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) represented as [[a,b],[c,d]]
params.name: mobius

docs.name: evaluateAtInf

docs.comment:
/**
 * Evaluates the given mobius function at a specific x.
 * 
 * @ignore

 * @param {number} x - The x value at which to evaluate
 * M(x) = (ax + b) / (cx + d) represented as [[a,b],[c,d]]
 * @returns {number} The result of the evaluation.
 */
docs.description: Evaluates the given mobius function at a specific x.

docs.comment:
/**
 * Returns the maximum value within the supplied array of numbers.
 * @ignore 
 */
docs.description: Returns the maximum value within the supplied array of numbers.
docs.name: max

docs.comment:
/**
 * Returns the maximum magnitude value within the supplied array of 
 * numbers.
 * @ignore 
 */
docs.description: Returns the maximum magnitude value within the supplied array of numbers.
docs.name: maxabs

docs.comment:
/**
 * Finds an upper bound on the magnitude (absolute value) of the roots
 * (including complex roots) of the given polynomial using Rouche's 
 * Theorem with k = n. This function is fast but not tight.
 * 
 * @ignore
 * @param p {number[]} p - The polynomial.
 * @returns {number} The bound.
 */
docs.description: Finds an upper bound on the magnitude (absolute value) of the roots(including complex roots) of the given polynomial using Rouche's Theorem with k = n. This function is fast but not tight.
docs.name: rootMagnitudeUpperBound_rouche

docs.comment:
/**
 * Finds an upper bound on the magnitude (absolute value) of the roots
 * of the given polynomial using the near-optimal Fujiwara bound. Note
 * that the bound includes complex roots. The bound is tight but slow 
 * due to usage of Math.pow().
 * 
 * @see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Properties_of_polynomial_roots#cite_note-Fujiwara1916-4
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial.
 * @returns {number} The bound.
 * @example
 * FloPoly.rootMagnitudeUpperBound_fujiwara([2,-3,6,5,-130]); //=> 6.753296750770361
 * FloPoly.allRoots([2,-3,6,5,-130]); //=> [-2.397918624065303, 2.8793785310848383]
 */
docs.description: Finds an upper bound on the magnitude (absolute value) of the rootsof the given polynomial using the near-optimal Fujiwara bound. Notethat the bound includes complex roots. The bound is tight but slow due to usage of Math.pow().
docs.name: rootMagnitudeUpperBound_fujiwara

docs.comment:
/** *

* Returns an upper bound for the positive real roots of the given * polynomial. *

*

* See algoritm 6 of the paper by Vigklas, Akritas and Strzeboński, * specifically the LocalMaxQuadratic algorithm hence LMQ. *

* * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial * @returns {number} A lower bound. * @example * FloPoly.positiveRootUpperBound_LMQ([2,-3,6,5,-130]); //=> 4.015534272870436 * FloPoly.positiveRootUpperBound_LMQ([2,3]); //=> 0 * FloPoly.positiveRootUpperBound_LMQ([-2,-3,-4]); //=> 0 */
docs.description:
Returns an upper bound for the positive real roots of the given polynomial.

See algoritm 6 of the paper by Vigklas, Akritas and Strzeboński, specifically the LocalMaxQuadratic algorithm hence LMQ.
docs.name: positiveRootUpperBound_LMQ

docs.comment:
/** *

* Calculates a lower bound for the positive roots of the given * polynomial. *

*

* See algoritm 6 of the paper by Vigklas, Akritas and Strzeboński, * specifically the LocalMaxQuadratic algorithm hence LMQ. *

* * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial * @returns {number} A lower bound. * @example * FloPoly.positiveRootLowerBound_LMQ([2,-3,6,5,-130]); //=> 1.6883241876925903 * FloPoly.positiveRootLowerBound_LMQ([2,3]); //=> 0 * FloPoly.positiveRootLowerBound_LMQ([-2,-3,-4]); //=> 0 */
docs.description:
Calculates a lower bound for the positive roots of the given polynomial.

See algoritm 6 of the paper by Vigklas, Akritas and Strzeboński, specifically the LocalMaxQuadratic algorithm hence LMQ.
docs.name: positiveRootLowerBound_LMQ

docs.comment:
/**
 * See positiveRootUpperBound_LMQ
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @returns {number} An upper bound.
 */
docs.description: See positiveRootUpperBound_LMQ
docs.name: negativeRootUpperBound_LMQ

docs.comment:
/**
 * See positiveRootLowerBound_LMQ
 * 
 * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial
 * @returns {number} A lower bound.
 */
docs.description: See positiveRootLowerBound_LMQ
docs.name: negativeRootLowerBound_LMQ

docs.comment:
/** *

* Approximate condition number for polynomial evaluation multiplied * by the exact value of the polynomial evaluation. *

*

* See Compensated Horner Scheme - paragraph 1.1 *

* * @ignore * @param {number[]} p - The polynomial * @param {number} x - The evaluation point * @returns {number} The condition number multiplied exact polynomial * value at x */
docs.description:
Approximate condition number for polynomial evaluation multiplied by the exact value of the polynomial evaluation.

See Compensated Horner Scheme - paragraph 1.1

returns.description: The condition number multiplied exact polynomial value at x

docs.name: conditionNumber

docs.comment:
/** *

* Classic rule of thumb approximate error bound using Horner's method * to evaluate polynomials. *

*

* http://www-pequan.lip6.fr/~jmc/polycopies/Compensation-horner.pdf *

* @param p {number[]} - The polynomial * @param x {number} - Value at which polynomial is evaluated. * @returns {number} The error bound */
docs.description:
Classic rule of thumb approximate error bound using Horner's method to evaluate polynomials.

http://www-pequan.lip6.fr/~jmc/polycopies/Compensation-horner.pdf

params.description: Value at which polynomial is evaluated.
params.name: x

docs.name: hornerErrorBound
